name: Dynamic Health Data Sharing Control
description: This use case enables older adults and their caregivers to dynamically manage and personalize the sharing boundaries of health data within ALFRED, ensuring both transparency and control while supporting effective and personalized remote care.
scenario:
Elena Rivera sat comfortably in her living room, her ALFRED device perched nearby, ready to assist. A tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, Elena was eager to explore every feature, especially those that allowed her to share health information freely. Today, she was testing ALFRED’s new dynamic health data sharing controls. “ALFRED, show me what data Sarah can see right now,” she asked aloud, genuinely wanting to understand the system’s transparency. The assistant responded with a clear summary, but Elena, true to her open-minded personality, immediately toggled settings to allow more real-time updates, excited by the prospect of her caregiver being constantly informed.

Meanwhile, Sarah Thompson, Elena’s informal caregiver, was balancing the care of several clients from her home office. When she received a notification from ALFRED about Elena’s latest health data sharing preferences, she felt a familiar tension. Sarah appreciated Elena’s openness but worried about the flood of unfiltered data she might receive, which could overload her already packed schedule. She wished for more control, preferring to manually select which data to review and when, rather than being bombarded by continuous streams. Yet, she knew Elena’s enthusiasm for sharing was part of what kept her motivated and engaged. Sarah hesitated but decided to respect Elena’s autonomy, reminding herself that flexibility was key in caregiving.

Later that afternoon, Elena spoke to ALFRED about her willingness to accept spontaneous video check-ins. “ALFRED, let Sarah call me anytime she wants,” she said with a smile. Sarah received an alert but hesitated before initiating a spontaneous video call, mindful of balancing professional boundaries and Elena’s wishes. She sent a quick message through ALFRED instead, asking if Elena was comfortable with a video chat now or preferred to schedule it. Elena responded promptly, appreciating the respect shown, but also reinforcing her desire for openness and immediacy in communication.

Their interaction revealed a natural friction: Elena thrived on full transparency and constant connectivity, while Sarah sought manageable data flows and care routines that respected both her time and professional boundaries. ALFRED, acting as the mediator, adapted dynamically—allowing Elena to experiment with sharing settings while providing Sarah with tools to filter and prioritize notifications. This ongoing negotiation underscored the complex balance between independence and care, autonomy and oversight, reflecting the real-world challenges faced by older adults and their caregivers.
